title: Dussehra 2015: Know how to celebrate dussehra in different parts of India
text:
Dussehra 2015: Know how to celebrate dussehra in different parts of India By India.com Staff on October 22, 2015 at 2:42 AM Comments 
The nine day festival of Navratri has come to conclusion with Dussehra. This year both Navami and Dashami are coinciding on the same day. The Navratri festival is celebrated by worshipping nine forms of Goddess Durga. The nine day long festivity culminates on the tenth day of Dussehra or Vijayadashami. This is one of the most grand festivla that is looked forward by people in India as they celebrate this festive season with much with zeal and fervor. It symbolizes victory of good over evil. Another peculiar thing about Dussehra is that it is celebrated in different ways in different parts of India. Let us explore how the festival is celebrated in different parts of the country. (ALSO READ: India’s first transgender Durga Puja idol in Kolkata is breaking stereotypes in Navratri 2015!) 
Durga Puja 
In Bengal, Orissa and Assam Dussehra, Dussehra is celebrated as Durga Puja. Bengal celebrates Durga Puja for 5 days, while in Orrisa and Assam it is a 4-day festival. the celebrations last for 4 days. People worship the idol of goddess Durga at homes and in public Pandals on the fifth day. They celebrate Durga puja on the days of sashti, Saptami, Ashtami and Navami. The festivity ends with a grand puja held on the tenth day where Bengali women perform a ritual called Sindoor Khela or Sindoor Utsav. The women offer Sindoor on the forehead of the goddess Durga and then on each other. It holds a lot of importance for married women, they apply Sindoor on each other wishing each other happy married life and good luck. 
Kullu Dussehra 
Dussehra of Kullu in Himachal Pradesh is the major attractions of Kullu valley.People indulge in this festivity with much enthusiasm on Dashmi. Kullu Dussehra is celebrated in Dhalpur maidan. The practice of the rituals of Kullu Dussehra dates back to the 17th century. An idol of Raghunath was installed by a King named Jagat Singh, followed by this, he was declared as the ruling deity,whom people worship till date. 
Mysore Dasara 
Mysore Dasara is celebrated by people of Mysore in the most colourul way. Floral decorations and lights adorn every household and locality. They have a ritual where they conduct a procession with elephants taking part in the festivity. The effigies of Ravana, Meghnath and Kumbhkaran are then burnt to symbolise the victory of good over evil. The Mysore palace is illuminated for a whole month during the festive season of Dussehra. On the tenth day that is Vijaydashami, the goddess Chamundeshwari is worshiped followed by a grand procession. 
Navratra 
Dussehra is celebrated in the form of Navratra in Gujarat.People celebrate the nine day long festival by playing the folk dance of Garba to folk songs. People wear traditional attire and gather for the Garba. Post the worship of the goddess, people play Garba through the night. It is truly beautiful, the Navratra depicts the liveliness, rich tradition of Gujarat. 
Dussehra 
In Maharashtra people celebrate the Navratri festival and worship nine forms of goddess Durga. Dussehra celebrates the Hindu god Rama’s victory over Ravan and the victory of good over evil. The nine day festival culminates with Dussehra, which is considered as an auspicious day to start anything new. Dussehra is also celebrated in Nepal, Indonesia, Malaysia, Sri Lanka, China and Thailand. Happy Dussehra to all! (ALSO READ: Here’s why we need to stop burning Ravana effigies on Dussehra)
